New Records: The Mavericks passed out 33 assists on Wednesday in the 119-99 victory over Chicago, a season best.
Key Match Events: The Mavericks played faster and the ball was whizzing around the court, which meant fewer half-court sets that gave defenders time to gear up for a stand.
The Mavericks were up 56-45 at halftime, and one of the reasons the Bulls were still in the game is that they had a plus-10 rebounding advantage late in the first half.
The Mavericks corrected that in the second half, giving the Bulls just five second-chance points (the Mavs had 12 after getting zero in the first half).
Pre-Game Insights: Coach Jason Kidd emphasized the importance of ball movement and getting the point across to players that there can be more than one right answer when attacking an opponent.
Kyrie Irving and Luka Dončić's ability to give the ball to teammates is to the betterment of the greater good.
Post-Match Reflections: Dwight Powell stepped in at backup center with Dereck Lively II out and provided solid minutes when the Mavericks were pulling away from the Bulls.
O-Max Prosper was solid enough to give Naji Marshall and Klay Thompson some rest periods.
Markieff Morris may join Powell and Prosper in getting meaningful minutes for the Mavericks.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mavericks were missing three rotation players (one of them starter P.J. Washington) but were able to mix and match to get the job done.
Marshall's versatility was lauded by Coach Kidd, and he was plus-18 during his 21 minutes on the floor.
The Mavericks' roster is deep enough to withstand injuries.
Others: The depth on the front line is going to be tested for however long Lively, Washington, and Kleber are out.
The Mavericks won't be able to rack up 30-ish assists every game, simply because some teams will play a slower pace or game-plan to force one-on-one play.
